source.title: Meghadūta
source.author: Kālidāsa
source.description: The Cloud Messenger - a yakṣa exiled to Rāmagiri sends a message to his beloved in the Himalayas via a passing cloud. Written in the mandākrāntā meter, it combines longing, nature description, and geographic journey.

passages.title: The Exiled Yakṣa
passages.sanskrit:
कश्चित्कान्ताविरहगुरुणा स्वाधिकारात्प्रमत्तः
शापेनास्तंगमितमहिमा वर्षभोग्येण भर्तुः ।
यक्षश्चक्रे जनकतनयास्नानपुण्योदकेषु
स्निग्धच्छायातरुषु वसतिं रामगिर्याश्रमेषु ॥
passages.padaccheda: कश्चित् कान्ता-विरह-गुरुणा स्व-अधिकारात् प्रमत्तः शापेन अस्तंगमित-महिमा वर्ष-भोग्येण भर्तुः यक्षः चक्रे जनक-तनया-स्नान-पुण्य-उदकेषु स्निग्ध-छाया-तरुषु वसतिम् रामगिरि-आश्रमेषु
passages.transliteration:
kaścit kāntā-viraha-guruṇā svādhikārāt pramattaḥ
śāpenāstaṃgamita-mahimā varṣa-bhogyena bhartuḥ |
yakṣaś cakre janaka-tanayā-snāna-puṇyodakeṣu
snigdha-chāyā-taruṣu vasatiṃ rāmagiry-āśrameṣu ||
passages.translation: A certain yakṣa, negligent of his duties due to the weight of separation from his beloved, his glory eclipsed by a curse from his master lasting a year, made his dwelling in the hermitages of Rāmagiri—where the waters are sanctified by Sītā's bathing, beneath trees of cool shade.
passages.grammarNotes:
This verse showcases several key grammatical features:

1. **Bahuvrīhi compounds**: कान्ताविरहगुरुणा (heavy with separation from beloved) - the compound describes the yakṣa, not the separation itself

2. **Tatpuruṣa compounds**: वर्षभोग्येण (to-be-enjoyed-for-a-year = lasting a year)

3. **Instrumental case**: शापेन (by a curse), गुरुणा (by the weight) - expressing cause/means

4. **Locative case**: उदकेषु, तरुषु, आश्रमेषु - indicating location of dwelling

passages.title: Months of Separation
passages.sanskrit:
तस्मिन्नद्रौ कतिचिदबलाविप्रयुक्तः स कामी
नीत्वा मासान्कनकवलयभ्रंशरिक्तप्रकोष्ठः ।
आषाढस्य प्रथमदिवसे मेघमाश्लिष्टसानुं
वप्रक्रीडापरिणतगजप्रेक्षणीयं ददर्श ॥
passages.padaccheda: तस्मिन् अद्रौ कतिचित् अबला-विप्रयुक्तः सः कामी नीत्वा मासान् कनक-वलय-भ्रंश-रिक्त-प्रकोष्ठः आषाढस्य प्रथम-दिवसे मेघम् आश्लिष्ट-सानुम् वप्र-क्रीडा-परिणत-गज-प्रेक्षणीयम् ददर्श
passages.transliteration:
tasminn adrau katicit abalā-viprayuktaḥ sa kāmī
nītvā māsān kanaka-valaya-bhraṃśa-rikta-prakoṣṭhaḥ |
āṣāḍhasya prathama-divase megham āśliṣṭa-sānuṃ
vapra-krīḍā-pariṇata-gaja-prekṣaṇīyaṃ dadarśa ||
passages.translation: On that mountain, separated from his slender wife, that love-sick one, having passed some months with forearms empty from the slipping of golden bracelets, on the first day of Āṣāḍha saw a cloud embracing the peak—resembling an elephant playfully butting a rampart.
passages.grammarNotes:
Key grammatical points:

1. **Perfect tense**: ददर्श (he saw) - reduplicative perfect of √दृश्

2. **Absolutive/gerund**: नीत्वा (having passed) - from √नी with -त्वा suffix

3. **Long compound chains**: कनकवलयभ्रंशरिक्तप्रकोष्ठः - "having forearms empty from the falling of golden bracelets" - describes the yakṣa's wasting away from grief

passages.title: The Request to the Cloud
passages.sanskrit:
धूमज्योतिःसलिलमरुतां सन्निपातः क्व मेघः
सन्देशार्थाः क्व पटुकरणैः प्राणिभिः प्रापणीयाः ।
इत्यौत्सुक्यादपरिगणयन्गुह्यकस्तं ययाचे
कामार्ता हि प्रकृतिकृपणाश्चेतनाचेतनेषु ॥
passages.padaccheda: धूम-ज्योतिः-सलिल-मरुताम् सन्निपातः क्व मेघः सन्देश-अर्थाः क्व पटु-करणैः प्राणिभिः प्रापणीयाः इति औत्सुक्यात् अपरिगणयन् गुह्यकः तम् ययाचे काम-आर्ताः हि प्रकृति-कृपणाः चेतन-अचेतनेषु
passages.transliteration:
dhūma-jyotiḥ-salila-marutāṃ sannipātaḥ kva meghaḥ
sandeśārthāḥ kva paṭu-karaṇaiḥ prāṇibhiḥ prāpaṇīyāḥ |
ity autsukyād aparigaṇayan guhyakas taṃ yayāce
kāmārtā hi prakṛti-kṛpaṇāś cetanācetaneṣu ||
passages.translation: Where is a cloud—a mere combination of smoke, fire, water, and wind? And where are messages, to be carried by living beings with keen senses? Yet, out of longing, not considering this, the yakṣa beseeched it—for those afflicted by love are naturally pathetic regarding both the conscious and unconscious.
passages.grammarNotes:
This verse demonstrates philosophical doubt before the central conceit:

1. **क्व...क्व construction**: "Where is X, where is Y?" - rhetorical expression of incompatibility

2. **Dvandva compound**: धूमज्योतिःसलिलमरुताम् - "of smoke, fire, water, and winds" (genitive plural)

3. **Gerundive (future passive participle)**: प्रापणीयाः - "to be carried"

4. **Present participle**: अपरिगणयन् - "not considering"
